H0.text: Absorb food is what a sea anemone uses poisonous darts to do.

H1.text: Defending itself is what a sea anemone does by using poisonous darts.

H2.text: Attract a mate is what a sea anemone uses poisonous darts to achieve.

H3.text: Protect its young is what a sea anemone uses poisonous darts to.

A4.text: The venom from cnidocytes paralyzes prey, enabling the anemone to move it to the mouth for digestion.

A5.text: Acorrhagi and acontia are used by sea anemones to drive off other anemones during battles.

A6.text: Sea anemones use cnidocytes to sting other anemones in order to defend or win space.

A7.text: Non-penetrant sticky cnidocytes in sea anemones help capture prey by sticking to them.

A8.text: Predatory species use their cnidocytes to poison or entangle prey, and those with venomous nematocysts may start digestion by injecting digestive enzymes.

A9.text: The 'smell' of fluids from wounded prey makes the tentacles fold inwards and wipe the prey off into the mouth.
